mainText:
The expansion of the human brain was one of the most rapid episodes of evolution of complex organs in the history of life.
The definitive part of the long creation story evidently began with the primitive Homo habilis (or a species closely related to it) two million years ago.
Prior to the habilines the prehumans had been animals.
Largely vegetarians, they had human-like bodies, but their cranial capacity remained chimpanzee-size, at or below 500 cubic centimeters.
Starting with the habiline period the capacity grew precipitously: to 680 cubic centimeters in Homo habilis, 900 in Homo erectus, and about 1,400 in Homo sapiens.
shownText:
We instinctively delight in the telling of countless stories about others as players upon the inner stage.
The best of it is expressed in the creative arts, political theory, and other higher-level activities we have come to call the humanities.
Today, at the terminus of this evolutionary process, our immense memory banks are smoothly activated across the past, present, and future.
They allow us to evaluate the prospects and consequences variously of alliances, bonding, sexual contact, rivalries, domination, deception, loyalty and betrayal.
The social intelligence of the campsite-anchored prehumans evolved as a kind of non-stop game of chess.

The expansion of the human brain was one of the most rapid episodes of evolution of complex organs in the history of life.
The definitive part of the long creation story evidently began with the primitive Homo habilis (or a species closely related to it) two million years ago.
Prior to the habilines the prehumans had been animals.
Largely vegetarians, they had human-like bodies, but their cranial capacity remained chimpanzee-size, at or below 500 cubic centimeters.
Starting with the habiline period the capacity grew precipitously: to 680 cubic centimeters in Homo habilis, 900 in Homo erectus, and about 1,400 in Homo sapiens.

At present there are two competing theories of the principal force.
Altruism in turn engenders complex social organization, and, in the one case that involves big mammals, human-level intelligence.
Still, to recognize the rare coming together of cooperating primates is not enough to account for the full potential of modern humans that brain capacity provides.
The first is kin selection: individuals favor collateral kin (relatives other than offspring) making it easier for altruism to evolve among members of the same group.
Evolutionary biologists have searched for the grandmaster of advanced social evolution, the combination of forces and environmental circumstances that bestowed greater longevity and more successful reproduction on the possession of high social intelligence.
title: The Riddle of the Human Species - NYTimes.com
